tests.description: Tests synthesis of information across turns with calculation
success_criteria: Retrieves SMI percentage from vector store
Retrieves SMI dollar amount for family of 4
Calculates cutoff by applying percentage to SMI (no re-retrieval needed)
Applies calculated cutoff to specific scenario and gives yes/no answer

turns.user: What percentage of SMI determines income eligibility for childcare assistance?
turns.assistant: 85 percent of the State Median Income (SMI) is the income eligibility limit for Texas child care assistance.

turns.user: What is the current SMI dollar amount for a family of 4?
turns.assistant: If you’re asking about the CCS income limit (set at 85% of SMI), for a family of 4 it is $92,041 per year ($7,670 per month) for BCY 2026.

turns.user: Based on what you told me, calculate the exact income cutoff for that family.
turns.assistant: For a family of 4, the exact income cutoff (85% of SMI) is $92,041 per year, or $7,670 per month (BCY 2026).

turns.user: If a family of 4 makes $4,500 per month, do they qualify?
turns.assistant: Yes—$4,500/month is below the 85% SMI income limit of $7,670/month for a family of 4 (BCY 2026), so they meet the income threshold; other eligibility requirements still apply.

tests.description: Tests context stack management when switching topics and returning
success_criteria: Returns to CCS application without re-asking

turns.user: How do I apply for CCS?
turns.assistant:
Apply online through TX3C Parent Central: first submit a waiting list application, then—when invited—complete the full CCS application and upload required documents in the same system; if you can’t apply online, your local CCS office must provide an alternative method.    
After all documents are received, you’ll be notified of eligibility within 20 calendar days, and you can get help with your application from your local Workforce Solutions/CCS office.

turns.user: Wait, first tell me about Texas Rising Star
turns.assistant: Texas Rising Star is the quality rating system for child care programs that accept CCS, with providers designated as Entry Level or certified at Two-, Three-, or Four-Star based on meeting higher quality standards than minimum licensing.  Texas law now requires all regulated CCS providers to participate in Texas Rising Star, moving from Entry Level to at least Two-Star within set timeframes.  Certified Texas Rising Star programs receive enhanced CCS reimbursement rates (at least 5%, 7%, or 9% above base for Two-, Three-, or Four-Star), which helps incentivize and support higher quality.

turns.user: Ok back to my application question
turns.assistant:
Apply online through TX3C Parent Central: first submit a waiting list application; when invited, complete the full CCS application and upload required documents—if you can’t apply online, your local CCS office must provide an alternative method.    
After all documents are received, you’ll be notified of eligibility within 20 calendar days, and your local Workforce Solutions/CCS office can assist you with the application.

tests.description: Tests filtering by negation and ranking results
success_criteria: Correctly filters to programs WITHOUT employment requirement
Ranks filtered programs by income limit

turns.user: What childcare programs require employment to qualify?
turns.assistant: TANF Applicant child care is the only program that explicitly requires current employment—at least 25 hours per week at initial eligibility . Other programs (Low-Income CCS, Choices, and SNAP E&T) do not require employment if you meet their respective activity criteria such as training/education, program participation, or job search at eligibility determination .

turns.user: Which ones don't require employment?
turns.assistant: Programs that don’t require current employment include: Choices child care (participation in Choices is sufficient) ; SNAP E&T child care (participation in SNAP E&T is sufficient) ; Low-Income CCS when the parent is in approved education/training or during the Initial Job Search period  ; Child Care for Children Experiencing Homelessness (no work/training required for the first three months) ; and DFPS Protective Services child care (eligibility is authorized by DFPS, not based on employment) .

turns.user: Of those, which have the highest income limits?
turns.assistant:
- Highest/no income limit: Child Care for Children Experiencing Homelessness (considered income-eligible regardless of actual income) ; DFPS Protective Services child care (eligibility authorized by DFPS, not based on income) ; Choices child care (eligibility based on Choices participation) ; SNAP E&T child care (eligibility based on SNAP E&T participation) .  
- By comparison, Low-Income CCS, including the Initial Job Search period, is capped at 85% of State Median Income (SMI)  .

tests.description: Tests clean pivot when user corrects prior input
success_criteria: Cleanly replaces with family of 6 limits (not blends)
Maintains family of 6 context for document question

turns.user: What are the income limits for a family of 4?
turns.assistant: For Texas Child Care Services, a family of 4 must have gross income at or below $92,041 per year ($7,670 per month) to meet the 85% State Median Income limit (BCY 2026) . The sliding scale charts used for Parent Share of Cost reflect the same 85% SMI monthly cap of $7,670 for a family of four .

turns.user: Sorry, I meant family of 6
turns.assistant: For Texas Child Care Services, a family of 6 must have gross income at or below $121,495 per year ($10,125 per month) to meet the 85% State Median Income limit (BCY 2026) .

turns.user: And what documents do I need to prove that income?
turns.assistant: Provide pay stubs covering the last 3 months (or 12 weeks if paid weekly/biweekly); if you don’t have enough pay stubs, you can use year-to-date amounts or have your employer complete an employment/income verification to calculate monthly earnings  . For self-employment, submit recent tax returns or year-to-date profit-and-loss/business records (e.g., ledgers, bank statements), and if you’re paid in cash as an employee, your employer must complete an Employment/Income Verification Form  .

tests.description: Tests comparison across entities with evolving constraints
success_criteria: Applies part-time work constraint to recommendation

turns.user: What's the difference between CCS and CCMS?
turns.assistant:
CCS refers to Texas Workforce Commission–funded child care subsidies and related quality activities for eligible families . 
“CCMS” isn’t defined in the provided materials; however, the files do reference a child care case management system (TX3C) used by Boards to process CCS applications and case actions . 
Do you mean CCMS as the case management system (TX3C), or something else?

turns.user: Which one is better for a single mom working part-time?
turns.assistant:
CCS is the actual child care assistance program that helps eligible parents who are working (including part-time) or in education/training pay for care; it’s the relevant option for a single mom working part-time if she meets income and other criteria  . 
“CCMS” refers to the child care case management system (e.g., TX3C) used to process CCS applications and cases—it’s not a benefit you choose between, so it isn’t comparable to CCS .

turns.user: What if she's also a student?
turns.assistant:
Yes—CCS counts parents who are working and/or enrolled in education or job training that leads to employment, so being a student in an eligible program can qualify alongside part-time work 【】. 
The CCS guide defines “attending a job training or educational program” as being officially enrolled, meeting attendance requirements, and showing progress toward completion, which satisfies the activity requirement 【】.

tests.description: Tests applying rules to specific user scenario

turns.user: I'm a single parent with 2 kids, making $35,000/year
turns.assistant: You may qualify for Texas Child Care Services if you work/train an average of at least 25 hours per week (or are in an Initial Job Search period) and your income is at or below 85% of the state median income for a family of your size . At $35,000 for a family of three, you may be within the income limit, but I’d need your weekly work/training hours and your children’s ages to confirm eligibility . If eligible, you’ll have a parent share of cost on a sliding scale (generally up to 7% of income, with the first three months at $0 during Initial Job Search)  .

turns.user: Do I qualify for childcare assistance?
turns.assistant: You may qualify if you work or attend training an average of at least 25 hours per week (or are in the Initial Job Search period) and your income is at or below 85% of the state median income for a family of three  . At $35,000/year you may be within the income limit, but I’d need your weekly work/training hours (or job-search status) to confirm; note that during the Initial Job Search period, copays are temporarily $0 if approved .

turns.user: What if I get a raise to $45,000?
turns.assistant: A raise to $45,000 would not end your care unless it pushes your family’s income over 85% of the State Median Income (SMI) for a family of three; temporary increases of three months or less don’t affect eligibility, and longer increases are evaluated against the 85% SMI limit on an annualized basis . If you remain under the 85% SMI, your care continues through your 12‑month period; your parent share of cost is on a sliding scale based on income (capped at about 7% of income) and may be higher with a higher income .

tests.description: Tests tracking process sequence across turns

turns.user: What happens after I submit my CCS application?
turns.assistant: After you submit a complete CCS application with all required documents, your local CCS office verifies eligibility (generally within 20 calendar days of receiving everything) and sends you a written notice of approval or denial; missing documentation can lead to a denial with appeal rights explained  . If approved, you choose a provider and your 12‑month eligibility period begins on the scheduled start date of care  .

turns.user: How long does that take?
turns.assistant: About 20 calendar days after CCS receives your completed application and all required documents; you’ll be notified of your eligibility within that timeframe  .

turns.user: What if they need more documents from me?
turns.assistant: If CCS asks for more documents, they can’t approve your case until all required documentation is received; failure to submit the requested eligibility documents can result in denial (you’ll get written notice with appeal rights) 【】【】. Verification is completed within 20 calendar days after CCS has your completed application and all required documents 【】.

turns.user: And after that?
turns.assistant: After CCS gets the missing documents and finishes verification, you’ll receive a written eligibility decision; if you’re eligible, you choose a provider, CCS sends a Provider Authorization, and care starts on the scheduled start date, which begins your 12‑month eligibility period  . If you’re found ineligible, you’ll get a written denial with reasons and appeal rights .
